Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal #: CNS 07-23054
PI(s): Fox, Geoffrey C.
Hayden, Linda B.; LeCompte, Malcolm; Pierce, Marlon E.; Stewart, Craig A.
Institution: Indiana University
Bloomington, IN 47402-1847
Title: MRI/Acq.: Acquisition of Polar Grid: Cyberinfrastructure for Polar Science

Project Proposed:

This project, acquiring a sophisticated instrument that addresses crucial ice-sheet science, enables a new generation of high resolution ice-sheet models with realistic boundary conditions that requires distributed PolarGrid Cyberinfrastructure to gather and process data and assimilate these with large simulations. PolarGrid consist of an intermittently disconnected field and base grids feeding information to "lower 48" data and computing resources. True real-time processing at the field camp is backed up with increasing fidelity, but increasing delay at the base and "lower 48" systems. The requested system includes an expedition grid consisting of ruggedized laptops in a field grid to a low power multi-core based camp cluster. A prototype and two production grids feed into a Teraflops system at Indiana and Elizabeth City State Universities. PolarGrid will be integrated with TeraGrid for both resource utilization and curricula sharing. Modern open data access standards will be followed so that raw processes, and simulated data can be archived outside PolarGrid by and for the science and engineering community. The innovative architecture of PolarGrid with intermittently disconnected components also has applications to other power- and bandwidth-challenged applications. The instrument responds to the recent polar satellite observations that show disintegration of ice shelves in Antarctica and the speed-up of several glaciers in Greenland.

Broader Impact: The infrastructure addresses an important current problem that touches all beings in one way or another, the key issue of polar ice disintegration. Strong educational activities are involved, mainly through the training of students. ECSU, a historically black university, involves undergraduate students through new curricula and research experiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed the electronic system (called Cyberinfrastructure by NSF) shown in "PolarGrid Schematic" to support experimental scientists from the NSF CReSIS (Center for Remote Sensing of Ice Sheets) project measuring the properties of ice sheets -- especially the depth of glaciers. This data when included in simulations enables a better understanding of ice-sheet dynamics which is a critical part of climate science allowing one to better understand the consequences of global warming. The cyberinfrastructure was optimized for the harsh weather environments illustrated in "expedition picture" and the need for operation in low electrical power environments. The techniques developed are applicable to other scientific and emergency management applications in remote regions. The equipment supported 9 separate exxpeditions from 2008-2011 gathering each time 5-100 terabytes of data. The equipment allowed experimentalists to detect instrumental failures and obtain early science results.

The data is shipped back to additional large scale computers situated at Indiana University (see "Polar Quarry computer" picture) and Elizabeth City State University. PolarGrid established these facilities which were used to support both research and education. The "Typical CReSIS data" picture shows the type of analysis performed. Novel image analysis algorithms identify the glacie bed automatically. These results are used in simulations by other researchers inside and outside CReSIS.

PolarGrid had a major education component as it established an instructional laboratory at Elizabeth City State University and supported many undergraduate researchers exploring Polar Science and Cyberinfrasture using the PolarGrid equipment. For the last two years over 30 undergraduates have been supported each summer in these research experiences. 75% of the students are from minority serving institutions so we support the broadening of the STEM pipeline. A highlight of summer 2011 was a special workshop to Historically Black Colleges and Universities faculty and students on cloud computing. See http://salsahpc.indiana.edu/admicloudyviewworkshop/
